message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modal Dependence Logic
Paper Abstract: We introduce a modal language which involves the concept of dependence. We give two game-theoretic definitions for the semantics of the language, and one inductive, and prove the equivalence of all three.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Inductive definition"

Links: [{"title":"Inductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Recursive definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recursive_definition"},{"title":"Inductive set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_set"},{"title":"Inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inference"},{"title":"Inductive sensor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_sensor"},{"title":"Deductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Field effect (chemistry) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_effect_(chemistry)"},{"title":"Syllogism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syllogism"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about inductive definitions:

## Definition

An inductive definition is used to define the elements in a set in terms of other elements in the set.(no content)An inductive definition of a set describes the elements in a set in terms of other elements in the set.

## Structure

Most recursive definitions have two foundations: a base case (basis) and an inductive clause.(no content)A recursive definition must always have base cases, cases that satisfy the definition without being defined in terms of the definition itself, and that all other instances in the inductive clauses must be "smaller" in some sense (i.e., closer to those base cases that terminate the recursion).

## Key Distinction

The main difference between an inductive definition and a circular definition is important: a circular definition may have no base case, and even may define the value of a function in terms of that value itself — rather than on other values of the function. Such a situation would lead to an infinite regress.

## Examples

Some examples of recursively definable objects include factorials, natural numbers, Fibonacci numbers, and the Cantor ternary set.

## Applications

Properties of recursively defined functions and sets can often be proved by an induction principle that follows the recursive definition. For example, the definition of the natural numbers directly implies the principle of mathematical induction for natural numbers.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Dependence"

Links: [{"title":"Substance dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Substance_dependence"},{"title":"Psychological dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_dependence"},{"title":"Dependency theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_theory"},{"title":"Dependency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency"},{"title":"Dependence analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependence_analysis"},{"title":"Data dependency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_dependency"},{"title":"Mean dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_dependence"},{"title":"Loop dependence analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loop_dependence_analysis"},{"title":"Physical dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_dependence"},{"title":"Independence (probability theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independence_(probability_theory)"}]

Based on the web search results, "dependence" has multiple meanings across different fields:

## Substance Dependence

Substance dependence, also known as drug dependence, is a biopsychological situation whereby an individual's functionality is dependent on the necessitated re-consumption of a psychoactive substance because of an adaptive state that has developed within the individual from psychoactive substance consumption that results in the experience of withdrawal and that necessitates the re-consumption of the drug.

There are two main types:
- **Physical Dependence**: Physical dependence is a physical condition caused by chronic use of a tolerance-forming drug, in which abrupt or gradual drug withdrawal causes unpleasant physical symptoms.

- **Psychological Dependence**: Psychological dependence develops through consistent and frequent exposure to a stimulus. After sufficient exposure to a stimulus capable of inducing psychological dependence (e.g., drug use), an adaptive state develops that results in the onset of withdrawal symptoms.

## Economic Context

Dependency theory is the idea that resources flow from a "periphery" of poor and exploited states to a "core" of wealthy states, enriching the latter at the expense of the former.

## Computer Science

A data dependency in computer science is a situation in which a program statement (instruction) refers to the data of a preceding statement.

## Mathematics & Statistics

Two events are independent, statistically independent, or stochastically independent if, informally speaking, the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of occurrence of the other or, equivalently, does not affect the odds. The opposite of this is dependence.

Web search results for query: "Modal logic"

Links: [{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"Normal modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_modal_logic"},{"title":"S5 (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S5_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic logic (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Regular modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_modal_logic"},{"title":"Category:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Non-normal modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-normal_modal_logic"},{"title":"Modal operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_operator"},{"title":"Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of modal logic:

## What is Modal Logic?

Modal logic is a kind of logic used to represent statements about necessity and possibility.(no content)In philosophy and related fields it is used as a tool for understanding concepts such as knowledge, obligation, and causation.

## Basic Structure

Modern treatments of modal logic begin by augmenting the propositional calculus with two unary operations, one denoting "necessity" and the other "possibility". The notation uses a prefixed "box" (□p) to denote "necessarily p" and a prefixed "diamond" (◇p) to denote "possibly p".(no content)In classical modal logic, □p (necessarily p) is equivalent to ¬◇¬p ("not possible that not-p") and ◇p (possibly p) is equivalent to ¬□¬p ("not necessarily not-p"), so these operators form a dual pair.

## Types of Modal Logic

There are various systems of modal logic. The smallest logic satisfying basic conditions is called K, and most modal logics commonly used nowadays with philosophical motivations (such as C. I. Lewis's S4 and S5) are normal extensions of K.(no content)Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic concerned with reasoning about knowledge, with applications in philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.(no content)Dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Basic Structure

Modern treatments of modal logic begin by augmenting the propositional calculus with two unary operations, one denoting "necessity" and the other "possibility". The notation uses a prefixed "box" (□p) to denote "necessarily p" and a prefixed "diamond" (◇p) to denote "possibly p".(no content)In classical modal logic, □p (necessarily p) is equivalent to ¬◇¬p ("not possible that not-p") and ◇p (possibly p) is equivalent to ¬□¬p ("not necessarily not-p"), so these operators form a dual pair.

## Types of Modal Logic

There are various systems of modal logic. The smallest logic satisfying basic conditions is called K, and most modal logics commonly used nowadays with philosophical motivations (such as C. I. Lewis's S4 and S5) are normal extensions of K.(no content)Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic concerned with reasoning about knowledge, with applications in philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.(no content)Dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about game-theoretic semantics:

## Overview

Game semantics is an approach to formal semantics that grounds the concepts of truth or validity on game-theoretic concepts, such as the existence of a winning strategy for a player.(no content)In this framework, logical formulas are interpreted as defining games between two players.

## Historical Development

In the late 1950s Paul Lorenzen was the first to introduce a game semantics for logic, and it was further developed by Kuno Lorenz.(no content)At almost the same time as Lorenzen, Jaakko Hintikka developed a model-theoretical approach known in the literature as GTS (game-theoretical semantics).

## Key Characteristics

The approach bears conceptual resemblances to ancient Socratic dialogues, medieval theory of Obligationes, and constructive mathematics.(no content)For most common logics, including the ones above, the games that arise from them have perfect information—that is, the two players always know the truth values of each primitive, and are aware of all preceding moves in the game.

## Modern Applications

Since the 1990s, game semantics has found important applications in theoretical computer science, particularly in the semantics of programming languages, concurrency theory, and the study of computational complexity.

Game-theoretic semantics represents an alternative approach to formal semantics alongside other methods like model-theoretic semantics and proof-theoretic semantics.
